skill.name: nextjs-devtools
skill.description:
Next.js development tooling via MCP. Inspect routes, components, build info, and debug Next.js apps.
Use when working on Next.js applications, debugging routing, or inspecting app structure.
NOT for general React or non-Next.js projects.
skill.summary: Inspect routes, components, and build info in Next.js apps via MCP server
skill.author: 92Bilal26

security_audit.summary: Legitimate Next.js development tooling. Static analyzer flagged Python f-strings as cryptographic patterns and subprocess.Popen as dangerous. These are false positives. The skill spawns a trusted MCP server package for Next.js inspection utilities.

low_findings.title: External command execution
low_findings.description: The skill spawns the Next.js devtools MCP server process using subprocess.Popen and npx. This is legitimate behavior for an MCP client skill, spawning trusted npm package 'next-devtools-mcp@latest'. Arguments come from skill configuration, not user input.

low_findings.title: HTTP network access
low_findings.description: The MCP client uses urllib for HTTP transport to communicate with MCP servers. This is standard MCP protocol behavior and expected for skills that use HTTP transport.

content.value_statement: Debugging Next.js applications is time-consuming without visibility into routes, components, and build configuration. This skill provides MCP-based tools to inspect app structure, list routes, examine components, and view build info directly from Claude.
actual_capabilities: List all routes in a Next.js application including API routes
Get detailed information about specific routes including handlers and parameters
List all React components used in the application
Retrieve build configuration and optimization settings
Read next.config.js settings and environment variables
limitations: Requires Next.js project with .next directory or after running next build
Does not modify or write to the Next.js application
Only works with Next.js projects, not standalone React apps
MCP server must be available via npx or running server process

use_cases.title: Explore Unknown Next.js Projects
use_cases.description: When joining a new Next.js codebase, use this skill to quickly understand the route structure, component organization, and build configuration without reading every file manually.

use_cases.title: Debug Route Matching Issues
use_cases.description: When routes are not matching as expected, use list-routes and get-route-info to verify which routes are registered and what handlers exist for specific paths.

use_cases.title: Review Build Configuration
use_cases.description: Before deployment or when troubleshooting build issues, inspect the actual build configuration being used including webpack settings, optimization flags, and environment variables.

prompt_templates.title: List All Application Routes
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the nextjs-devtools skill to list all routes in this Next.js application. Show me the route paths and their types (page, api, layout).

prompt_templates.title: Inspect Specific Route Details
prompt_templates.prompt: Use nextjs-devtools to get details about the route at /[path]. Show me the file handler, parameters, and any dynamic segment patterns.

prompt_templates.title: Find Component Usage
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the skill to list all React components in this application. Group them by where they are used (pages, layouts, or shared components).

prompt_templates.title: Check Build Configuration
prompt_templates.prompt: Run get-build-info and get-config to show me the current build configuration. Pay attention to webpack customizations, image optimization settings, and experimental features.

output_examples.input: List all routes in this Next.js application
List all components in this application

best_practices: Run next build before inspecting build info to ensure .next directory exists
Start the MCP server once and reuse it for multiple queries to reduce startup overhead
Use get-route-info after list-routes to understand specific route handlers and parameters
anti_patterns: Using this skill on non-Next.js projects (will not find routes or build info)
Expecting real-time updates without restarting the MCP server after code changes
Running list-components on very large applications without filtering may produce extensive output

faq.question: What is Next.js DevTools?
faq.answer: Next.js DevTools is an MCP server that provides tools for inspecting Next.js applications. It can list routes, components, build configuration, and next.config.js settings.

faq.question: Do I need to install anything?
faq.answer: The skill uses npx to run next-devtools-mcp@latest automatically. No global installation is required. Ensure you have Node.js and npm installed.

faq.question: How does this skill connect to Next.js DevTools?
faq.answer: The skill includes an MCP client script that can spawn the Next.js DevTools server via npx (stdio transport) or connect to a running server via HTTP.

faq.question: What is the difference between stdio and HTTP transport?
faq.answer: Stdio spawns a new server process for each command. HTTP connects to a persistent server. HTTP is faster for multiple queries but requires starting the server first with start-server.sh.

faq.question: Why is my build info empty?
faq.answer: Build info requires the .next directory. Run next build in your project before using get-build-info. Some settings may not appear in development mode.

faq.question: Can this modify my Next.js application?
faq.answer: No. This skill is read-only. It only inspects routes, components, and configuration without making any changes to your application files.
